title: Friday, 25th November, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:02 am
PM11:03am

Morning

PM11:03am

I have news!

PM11:04am

Not stock related news, but ML redesign news

11:04 am
PM11:04am

Had a good session with the techies yesterday and they've come up with a great potential solution to this so-called "letter box" issue

PM11:04am

Where by the amount of content here is restricted by the HUGE footer etc

PM11:05am

It will take a little time to implement, so please be patient

11:04 am
PM11:05am

But we are on the case

PM11:05am

We listen to feedback. Honest

PM11:05am

(basically, we've found away to get rid of all the clutter)_

11:05 am
undefined
PM11:06am

In markets news...

PM11:06am

Well, there are bits and pieces. But yes it's quiet

11:06 am
PM11:06am

Thanksgiving yesterday in the US and Black Friday today

PM11:07am

And there are all these lame attempts to import Black Friday to Britain

PM11:07am

Which means my inbox is full of rubbish

11:07 am
PM11:07am

Footsie off 5 points

PM11:08am

Shall we go to the main features that we do have Bryce

PM11:08am

Actelion already mentioned on the right

11:08 am
BE11:08am

Okay let's start there.

PM11:08am

Thumbs up

BE11:09am

As mentioned yesterday, though we're not brittle enough to claim any credit.

11:09 am
BE11:09am

Bloomberg beat us to the publish button.

BE11:09am

https://www.bloomb...drugmaker-actelion

PM11:09am

You were on it tho Bryce

11:09 am
PM11:09am

And today it's Rocket

PM11:09am

Up 15% currently

PM11:09am

181.60 on my screen

11:09 am
BE11:10am

Well, let's get in about this one.

BE11:10am

First, as Bloomberg reports, J&J seems to have approached Actelion about a potential takeover

BE11:10am

And as Bloomberg notes, we've been here before -- Amgen's interest in 2010, for instance, which also leaked -- but also says CEO and co-founder JP Clozel “may now be more open to entertaining a sale at a sufficient premium”.

11:10 am
BE11:10am

First thing to note is that Actelion doesn't have to respond.

BE11:10am

Swiss law is fine with all this.

BE11:11am

As we saw in Syngenta / Monsanto. Target can say nothing.

11:11 am
BE11:11am

So insiders, knock yourselves out.

BE11:11am

Much as you have been over the past month or so.

BE11:11am

Thanks to Olivetree for providing this Actelion implied volatility graph ...

11:11 am
BE11:11am

BE11:12am

So, yeah ... might've leaked a wee bit.

BE11:12am

Thanks also to Olivetree for the options data, which shows a notional $270m worth of upside calls traded.

11:12 am
PM11:12am

hehehe

BE11:12am

Actelion daily total options volume averaged ~$70m heading into this event. A more normal figure is ~$0.

BE11:12am

So we've talked before on here about how journalists are usually the last to know.

11:12 am
BE11:13am

The hot money arrives long before us.

BE11:13am

Which means the endless stonewalling and straight-out lying we have to deal with when trying to get to the truth only serves to perpetuate the false market.

BE11:13am

The result is ......... Actually, sod this.

11:13 am
BE11:13am

Here's what my notepad says.

PM11:13am

Excellent

BE11:13am

Everything I'm about to type is a rumour and is unconfirmed.

11:13 am
BE11:14am

We've sought to confirm it. But we haven't.

PM11:14am

So reader beware

BE11:14am

Yep. This is just what Mr Market believes.

11:14 am
BE11:14am

J&J made its offer on or around November 13. This is an rumour and is unconfirmed.

BE11:14am

That offer was around 240 Swiss francs. This is an rumour and is unconfirmed.

BE11:14am

JP Morgan and Goldman are advising J&J. This is an rumour and is unconfirmed.

11:14 am
BE11:15am

J&J's advisors gave Actelion a deadline of today to respond to that offer, otherwise it would go hostile. This is an rumour and is unconfirmed.

BE11:15am

Actelion has BOA Merrill Lynch doing its defence. This is a rumour and is unconfirmed.

BE11:15am

One line we've heard is that Actelion rejected the offer of around 240 Swiss francs on Wednesday and indicated that it was looking for something rather higher.

11:15 am
BE11:15am

As in, higher by 30 sfr or thereabouts.

BE11:15am

A second line we've heard is that nothings been decided, and a deal is still possible in the 240-250 bracket.

BE11:16am

These are rumours.

11:15 am
PM11:16am

(Actelion going higher as you type)

BE11:16am

They are unconfirmed.

PM11:16am

(183.70)

11:16 am
BE11:16am

We don't know.

PM11:16am

(184)

BE11:16am

There are people out there who think they know, and we're not them.

11:16 am
BE11:16am

So let's turn back to stuff we do know.

BE11:16am

Clozel -- who's a more scientist than an corporate type -- hasn't historically wanted to sell.

BE11:17am

He fought off the vultures in 2010 with the argument that Actelion's pipeline was misunderstood by the market. Short-termism is damaging and all that.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

And he was proved right. Shares up threefold since. Shareholders should have his back.

BE11:17am

Also note that his opinion seems unchanged.

BE11:17am

This is what he said during a call with JPM in September ....

11:17 am
BE11:18am

"I do not intend to go on a beach and to enjoy life. My passion – and let’s be clear – is to discover drugs and provide them to the patients. I would say, give me three years – three to four years – to change completely Actelion and to have Actelion at another level as a company. I always have said, and when I started Actelion I said it to all the investors, my ambition is not to become a small biotech but to have as a model companies like Genentech, Biogen, Amgen – this level..”

BE11:18am

... Though his shareholding is only 5%.

BE11:18am

And the board would of course have an obligation to weigh up whether an offer in the mid 200s is more valuable than independence.

11:18 am
BE11:18am

Okay, I'm going to chuck up some grey here to give myself a break.

BE11:18am

Barclays .... They say "nah ..."

BE11:19am

M&A speculation is not new for Actelion – the company has been a prominent takeover target for years, with a recent Bloomberg report in April 2016 stating that Sanofi/JnJ were interested and other Bloomberg/Reuters articles in 2015 and 2010 that Shire and Amgen approached the company, respectively. We continue to believe that management, as quoted on many conference calls and public presentations, remains committed to Actelion as an independent company.

11:18 am
BE11:19am

Why the constant speculation? Firstly, the company is the strongest player in Pulmonary Arterial Hypertension (PAH) and has recently (and successfully) lifecycle managed its Tracleer franchise (once 90% of its group revenues, CHF1.5bn at peak) into new products Opsumit and Uptravi (our combined peak revenue estimate at CHF2.5bn). That means it yields strong earnings and cash flow momentum for any pharma company needing earnings accretion today. Secondly, the company’s R&D pipeline is, in our view, less attractive for a potential buyer and thus stripping out this cost base could potentially be a deal strategy. We note PAH is extremely sales force heavy so SG&A would have to remain. Thirdly, Actelion would also be a unique way for US corporations to use their offshore cash (ATLN and Shire remain more “affordable” companies for US buyers with no majority ownership by a family/corporation). While future US tax legislation may make repatriation of ex-US cash easier for US players, this potential transition could take up to two years, in our view. Fourthly, a more disciplined and challenging stance from US payers on pharmaceutical drug pricing has narrowed R&D returns for pharma players and while many look to strengthen pipeline potential they need a “earnings bridge” to bolster on in the meantime. We expect the M&A specualtion to continue but would be surprised if ATLN engaged.

BE11:19am

Jefferies ... they say "maybe ...."

BE11:19am

We forecast a compelling growth profile with at least +20% EPS CAGR from 2017E driven by PAH drugs Opsumit and Uptravi, with robust operating leverage. While we see few direct synergies with JNJ’s marketed drugs, the relatively long lifecycle of Actelion’s highly profitable PAH franchise, plus potentially overlooked pipeline opportunities, may be attractive to a number of large pharma, in our view. Shares were weak after 3Q results lateOct on heightened concerns on risks to Opsumit growth from 2018E once both Tracleer and Letairis are generic, plus a likely 2017E EPS decline as US Tracleer generics potentially launch 1Q17E, perhaps limiting the ability of mgmt to continue to “beat and raise”. The stock trades on 22x 2017E and 17x 2018E PE, with our NPV sum-of-the-parts valuation c.CHF180 per share.

11:19 am
BE11:19am

Morgan Stanley ... They say .....

BE11:19am

............. nothing much really.

BE11:20am

[W]e would view a potential for approximately CHF30 per share of costs savings in the event of a takeover, mainly from potential R&D savings, given Actelion's leaner SG&A costs. A cut
ranging from 30-40% of the existing cost base, close to recent transactions in the sector, would represent SFr400-500m annually (the entire R&D budget plus ~10% of SG&A), i.e. around SFr320-425m post tax annually. Several companies could have the ability to integrate Actelion's activities given its relatively focused area of expertise. Companies with activities in respiratory and cardiology plausibly could be attracted.

11:20 am
BE11:20am

Strong execution in 2016, ahead of US generic launches in 2017. As a reminder, Actelion's strong outperformance YTD has been driven by delayed US generics of Tracleer and strong launches of Opsumit & Uptravi. While US generics of Tracleer are widely expected in early 2017, we stand close to consensus on both Opsumit (2020 sales of CHF1.2bn) and Uptravi (2020 sales of CHF0.8bn), and see more limited room for further EPS upgrades

BE11:20am

JPM -- yes, them again! -- they say "bid frenzy!"

BE11:21am

If last night’s story is accurate, and Actelion are exploring a sale, we believe multiple potential acquirers could be attracted to the company’s PAH franchise (Opsumit and Uptravi, plus Tracleer which is genericising), which combined offer a strong growth profile, with Revenues growing from SFr2.1bn in 2016, to SFr2.7bn in our model by 2020, with Opsumit and Uptravi patent protection to the mid 2020s, and high profitability (40%+ EBIT margin for the group). We currently attribute little value to the pipeline/R&D function (7% of our NPV), but this could also hold appeal, as could the company’s loss Swiss tax rate (12.5%) and lack of financial leverage. In addition, as part of a larger company, there could be cost savings, particularily if there was significant therapeutic overlap.

11:21 am
BE11:21am

· We currently have a SFr160 price target, set at 19x 2017 PE (currently on c.19x). We currently calculate an NPV of SFr124 (8% cost of equity), with no terminal and cautious pipeline assumptions. Upside to fair value and uspide to our current NPV could exist if a potential acquirer were capable of deriving cost savings. An acquirer could also see potential upside vs. our standalone valuation if using a project finance cost of capital, rather than our 8% cost of equity.

BE11:21am

· With J&J having a market cap exceeding $300bn, Actelion would clearly be an affordable asset for the company. Less clear to us is the logic of the timing, ahead of a likely favourable ex-US cash repatriation window for US corporates. Actelion shares had been weak post Q3 results, but the logic for a move at this time is unclear to us. We also see little in the way of obvious therapeutic overlap to allow synergies, beyond J&J’s interest in the Xarelto anti-coagulant which could have some modest overlap with cardiologists prescribing PAH therapaies (we believe PAH is more pulmonologist focused).

BE11:21am

The list of alternative bidders is obvious, of course.

11:21 am
BE11:21am

Pfizer, Bristol, Shire, Glaxo, Sanofi, Amgen ...

BE11:22am

Many, some, all or fewer have been named in speculative stuff over the past half decade.

BE11:22am

And all of whom could do with a stable, relatively uncomplicated pharma with a decent collection of drugs and a pipeline that's unlikely to go spectacularly wrong.

11:22 am
BE11:22am

But to be clear, if we're taking about a firm offer, J&J is the only name we've heard.

PM11:23am

Suspect this might keep us busy for some months to come

BE11:23am

Have I said RAW? I should say RAW. RAW!

11:23 am
BE11:23am

Oh, and just as a wee postscript to all that ....

BE11:23am

A keen eye might note that Bloomberg's overnight five-paragraph story had nine bylines on it.

BE11:23am

Nine reporters, chasing one story, on Thanksgiving.

11:23 am
BE11:23am

Whereas we had one. Arash. Who was also writing half a dozen other stories.

BE11:24am

If you're uncomfortable with the thought of only one news organisation having the manpower required to pursue stories and maintain an honest market, the FT's subscription page is here: https://www.ft.com...-4ee2-8d58d9a9a4ea

BE11:24am

Thumbs up

11:24 am
undefined
PM11:24am

Blimey, thx for all that Bryce

BE11:24am

(I may have had slightly too much coffee this morning.)

11:24 am
BE11:24am

Should we head into more prosaic matters?

BE11:25am

Movers for instance?

PM11:25am

Why do i share some strat stuff while you get your breath back

11:25 am
BE11:25am

Good idea.

PM11:25am

Credit Suisse got a good "Inflation -- pain or gain?) thiing out

PM11:25am

But it's mainly illustrative

11:25 am
PM11:25am

And I'd usually usual place it

PM11:25am

But the Long Room is shut!

PM11:25am

So let me see what i can do

11:25 am
PM11:26am

Richard Kersley and team

PM11:26am

(You can always email me Wink smile )

PM11:26am

In this report, we have conducted a bottom-up stress test to assess the assumptions our relevant sector analysts are
adopting across more than 200 stocks for the cost and price components in their models, and where the greatest
sensitivities lie should price inflation exceed expectations.
Macro indicators on inflation shape such considerations, of course, with PPI and raw material indices in most
countries turning higher, and the UK the most pronounced given the weakness of sterling. However, these pressures are by
no means confined to the UK with deflation in EM reversing.

11:26 am
PM11:26am

Our recent proprietary corporate spending survey (Credit Suisse Executive Panel: Pricing pressure rising) provided
further and timely perspective on this. European firms are preparing to raise prices; a net 40% expect to increase prices in
the next six months versus net 14% in July, and -8% in May. We expect PMI price readings to rise in keeping with this.

PM11:26am

Such pricing intentions/hopes are almost certainly cost push driven. Hence, we detail the cost of goods sold
(COGS) exposure for companies and, importantly, our analysts’ perception of relative pricing power. Who can pass on cost
pressures, and who more generally has the pricing ability to take more than their fair share of an inflationary environment?

PM11:27am

We would note the cost assumptions analysts tend to make are relatively muted. To be fair, forecasting specific
input costs is not straight forward or always material. However, the risks look on the upside with few assuming, in anything
other than the UK where the NLW kicks in, that any future wage pressure emerges.

11:27 am
PM11:27am

Sectors with the highest COGS as a percent of sales include Food Retail, Steel and Paper/Packaging. Raw material cost
intensity is notable in these latter two, as well as Chemicals. Labour costs loom large as a percentage of revenue in IT
Software/Services and Business Services, but is highly relevant in the low margin consumer sectors.

PM11:27am

On the basis of flexing analyst price assumptions, we find sectors with the greatest leverage to changes to their EPS
estimates to a hypothetical increase in sales price include Transport, Steel, Chemicals and Building. Of these chemicals and
steel have the better pricing power on our analysts scores.

BE11:27am

(@Pharma: there's an element of that. But much like science publishing, there are people who will throw their grannies out of moving vehicles to get first byline on a big story.)

11:27 am
PM11:27am

We establish three screens of stocks from our analysts’ estimates and sensitivity analysis – “Low cost risk” (low COGS,
high pricing power), “Pass-through potential” (high COGS, high pricing power) and the “Margin challenges” (high COGS,
low pricing power). See pages 8-10.

PM11:28am

You're going to want those screens at least

PM11:28am

Give me a mo

11:03 am
PM11:03am

Welcome to Markets LIve

PM11:29am

PM11:29am

Right click to read

11:29 am
PM11:29am

High COGs...

PM11:29am

PM11:30am

Margin callenges...

11:30 am
PM11:30am

PM11:30am

Email me if you want more

undefined
11:31 am
PM11:31am

Legal eagle -- we have a very good internal lawyer

PM11:31am

Nigel Hanson

PM11:31am

He spends a lot of time with Alphavillains and ex-Alphavillains

11:31 am
PM11:32am

Shall we go to the movers Bryce?

BE11:32am

We make Nigel's life difficult and he makes ours easier.

PM11:32am

Thumbs up

11:32 am
BE11:32am

It's exactly the opposite relationship one usually has with a lawyer.

BE11:33am

Back to drugs, then.

AstraZeneca PLC (AZN:LSE): Last: 4,252, up 42 (+1.00%), High: 4,272, Low: 4,225, Volume: 602.99k
11:33 am
BE11:33am

Liberum turns positive, on valuation mostly

BE11:33am

"Market now pricing in zero for immune-oncology"

BE11:34am

... which I'm going to continue to argue is probably the correct valuation for I-O.

11:33 am
BE11:34am

The extremely patchy results shown so far from immune-oncology suggests it's never be anything other than a niche treatment.

BE11:34am

The fact is that basic research has basically given up on I-O as a dead end.

BE11:34am

So the pipeline of stuff coming through translational medicine has come to resemble legacy run-off rather than the brave new world of cancer cures we were being pitched a decade or so ago.

11:34 am
PM11:35am

oh no

BE11:35am

I failed GCSE Biology though, so my opinion might not be worth much.

BE11:35am

I expect Liberum's scribbler's better qualified.

11:35 am
BE11:35am

With the shares down c.20% from September highs, we believe the current valuation is effectively assuming zero from the high potential I-O programme. Whilst we have always believed the key MYSTIC study is higher risk than a typical Phase 3, de-risked peak sales potential from the programme are $6bn p.a. even on consensus numbers. This makes a zero implicit valuation for the asset a serious mispricing

BE11:36am

Major upside on success; limited downside on failure – we think the shares are worth up to £60-64 in the event of durva-treme success in the key Phase 3 studies reporting through 2017 (greater than 40% upside). In the event of failure, whilst there would likely be short term downside, we see fundamental value in the £45/share range (c.7% upside)

BE11:36am

• Earnings growth is attractive even ex-durva/treme – Notably, even without durva-treme, we think earnings growth of c.9% p.a. (2017-21) is achievable. If lower risk Tagrisso and Lynparza come through, 12% is more likely. We think this level of growth more than justifies upside to the current share price and is supportive of a range c.£45-48/share (7-14% upside) ex-durva-treme

11:36 am
BE11:36am

• Forecasts include prudent view on base business – The Q3 numbers suggested a deteriorated base business, particularly in respiratory and diabetes. Our forecasts now include ongoing 20% p.a. price cuts for Symbicort and c.10% below cons. estimates on key diabetes products

BE11:36am

• Sector trade-off overdone; Trump a major positive – The sector has derated c.25% since June 2015 and c.15% in the last three months into the US election. Overwhelmingly this has been driven by worries on US pricing. With the Clinton agenda set aside, a largely benign (and in places positive) Republican one in its place and analyst estimates already likely assuming much tighter pricing anyway, we see now as a key buying opportunity for a sector offering 8% CAGR growth for c.13x 2017 PE. As the remaining UK large cap we had on a HOLD, we can no longer justify keeping AZN on this rating

BE11:37am

• £52 TP offers 24% upside – using our previous methodology of separate valuations for the base pharma and biotech-like pipeline businesses, we get to a fair value of £52/share. Although this is unchanged from our September TP, it is 7% lower on a USD basis reflecting prudent base business assumptions

11:37 am
BE11:37am

Incidentally, I've been tryng to find $1bn-valued immuno-oncology startup so I can call it an immunicorn.

BE11:37am

If anyone can help, my email is the obvious one.

undefined
11:38 am
BE11:38am

What else, then?

PM11:38am

There very little corporate news around

BE11:38am

Yep, and volumes look rubbish.

11:38 am
PM11:38am

I was just trying to find out what's happening with this War Paint float

BE11:38am

Remind me .......

PM11:39am

Lipstick

11:38 am
BE11:39am

............ oh.

PM11:39am

I thought it had listed

PM11:39am

11:39 am
PM11:39am

It's raising 2.5m and the founders are taking 20m off the table

BE11:40am

That's usually a good sign, right?

PM11:40am

hehe

11:40 am
PM11:40am

The business was originally co-founded in 1992 by Sam Bazini and Eoin MacLeod operating solely in the close-out cosmetics and fragrance industry.

PM11:40am

The second and larger own-brand division consists primarily of the Group's flagship brand, W7. The W7 brand has grown organically since its inception in 2002 and now contains over 500 items which are sold into high street retailers and independent beauty shops across the UK, Europe, Australia and the US. In FY2015, the own-brand division contributed approximately 80% of the Group's total revenues and was supplied to over 230 customers in more than 40 countries. In addition to the W7 brand, the own-brand division has acquired and registered other brand names; though to date, these have been relatively undeveloped.

BE11:41am

Hm .... I'm anticipating some "putting lipstick on a pig" editorials in the near to mid-term future ....

11:41 am
undefined
PM11:41am

I see the chairman at Fastjet is scapering

Fastjet PLC (FJET:LSE): Last: 14.30, down 1.7 (-10.62%), High: 14.30, Low: 14.30, Volume: 181.95k
11:42 am
PM11:42am

Colin Child is off

PM11:42am

This looks a tad unstable

PM11:42am

Ugly trading update bere http://www.investe...1611250700061294Q/

11:42 am
PM11:43am

Here's a bit of Liberum on that

PM11:43am

Who are putting a brave face on things

PM11:43am

The stabilisation plan appears to be progressing well. The switch to smaller
aircraft is underway, with the anticipated operating cost reductions
confirmed by the initial experience with the first plane, and both load factors
and yields showing double-digit percentage improvements. However, the
implementation costs of the stabilisation plan have been higher than
expected, resulting in a greater strain on cash. The group now needs to
raise additional capital. In light of the uncertainty over the group's financial
position, we place our recommendation, target price and forecasts under
review.

11:43 am
PM11:43am

A key part of the stabilisation plan is the switch to smaller, cheaper aircraft. This is now underway with
two more Airbus A319s returned to lessors. The first wet leased Embraer E190 aircraft was put into
service in Tanzania in October. Based on the initial experience with this aircraft, management is
confident its original expectations of a 10-15% reduction in operating costs are achievable. Load
factors to date have shown an 18 point improvement, with average yields rising by approximately
12%.

PM11:44am

The route rationalisation process is nearing completion. The rationalisation of international routes
from Tanzania to Kenya, Uganda and Zimbabwe takes effect in early December. Flights are being
added to the Harare, Zimbabwe to Johannesburg, South Africa route, but the route between
Johannesburg and Victoria Falls, Zimbabwe will be suspended next month. Domestic routes in
Zimbabwe and Tanzania, and international routes from those countries to South Africa, are expected
by management to contribute to fixed costs through December, but will be monitored closely
thereafter

PM11:44am

You'd have to be brave, in my view

11:44 am
undefined
BE11:44am

Okay, trying to find out about this Inmarsat trade ....

BE11:45am

.... no luck yet. Will let you know when I do.

11:45 am
Inmarsat PLC (ISAT:LSE): Last: 736.00, up 14 (+1.94%), High: 737.00, Low: 718.00, Volume: 8.30m
BE11:46am

But I'm not at a proper screen and there's still a lack of bodies around to speak to. Note yesterday was the lowest-volume day of 2016 so far, incidentally.

PM11:46am

Hey, you seen this news Bryce?

11:46 am
PM11:47am

Ocado announces that this week it has commenced operations from its Andover CFC. Customer orders have been picked and delivered from the site starting earlier this week and we expect volumes will increase over the coming months.

PM11:47am

BE11:47am

11:47 am

Ocado Group PLC (OCDO:LSE): Last: 265.60, down 1.4 (-0.52%), High: 268.00, Low: 265.10, Volume: 32.88k
PM11:47am

Thought we'd get more excitement on that

11:49 am
BE11:49am

I'm not sure opening a thing that they said they'd open at the time they said they'd open it, which adds a bunch of idle capacity that they'll have to fill up with "your first five orders for just £50" tokens, is entirely significant to the investment case.

undefined
BE11:49am

So ............. What else. Sellside?

11:49 am
PM11:50am

Sure

BE11:50am

Morgan Stanley's knife-catching Mediclinic ....

Mediclinic International PLC (MDC:LSE): Last: 725.50, up 1.5 (+0.21%), High: 742.00, Low: 723.00, Volume: 422.36k
11:50 am
BE11:51am

How many profit warnings recently? At least two.

BE11:51am

Anyway, they reckon the next one's in the price.

BE11:51am

The outcome of regulatory challenges in Switzerland and the Middle East has created uncertainty. The focus is on the bear case, we think. While there is downside risk, we do not think
the benefit of a strong management team navigating a tough situation is priced in. Upgrade to Overweight.

11:51 am
BE11:52am

Regulatory overhang. Two regulatory challenges are impacting MEI/MDC (1) The potential Zurich tax on Klinik Hirslanden - which could potentially have a CHF 34 - 39 million earnings impact; and (2) The Thiqa co-payment regulation which is driving away volumes in Abu Dhabi, and where management have guided revenue down by another AED 150 million.

BE11:52am

Headwinds won't turn in the near term, but largely priced in... We are not suggesting that these two challenges are likely to reverse, or have no impact. In fact, we think these two headwinds will wipe out £1.80 from our valuation, should they persist. What we are suggesting is that after a 35% sell off over the last quarter, that the potential financial and valuation impact has largely been captured.

BE11:52am

Attractive risk reward. Regulation in both regions could serve as an overhang for some time, and there will be some near-term pressures. However, over the next 12 - 18 months, some mitigating circumstances could prevent this downside playing out. We look to the bear to bull case scenarios to assess this risk. In our bull case scenario we forecast a business result that we think management could achieve in a normalized environment without any regulatory interference. Here we see +37% upside. Our bear case assumes the Zurich tax hits FY18 HEPS and beyond, and the Middle East to sees little recovery from H2 2017 levels. We see 12% downside should this play out. The stock is trading at levels where, should there be a further 5 to 10% sell off, the share would be trading close to our bear case. While we have 12% upside to our base case price target, we think the market should be focussed on this risk reward profile.

11:53 am
BE11:53am

Bringing downgrades into our forecasts. We cut our forecast earnings by 15-8% driven primarily by downgrades to the Middle East region, and bring Tarmed reduction from FY18 onwards. We are currently 2-4% below consensus on our forecast years, but anticipate some downgrades to follow. We cut our price target from £9.00 to £8.25, which implies 12% upside potential. Upgrade to OW
